para_sentences.para_0: We have seen different kinds of problems until now. In this section, we will look at those problems that have been intriguing researchers for a very long time. We will explore what these problems are called and see how to identify these problems (CLO7). We will then look at a few approximation strategies that will help us approximately solve these algorithms (CLO6).
After successful completion of this module, you should be able to do the following (in addition to answering the questions listed below):

ol_0: Explain P  NP  NP-Complete and NP-Hard complexity classes (CLO7)    What are the complexity classes? What is meant by P  NP  NP-Hard and NP-Complete? What are some examples of P  NP  NP-Complete and NP-Hard problems? What do we mean when we say a problem is NP-Complete? What do we mean by reduction?
What is meant by P  NP  NP-Hard and NP-Complete?
What are some examples of P  NP  NP-Complete and NP-Hard problems?
What do we mean when we say a problem is NP-Complete?
What do we mean by reduction?
Explain how a problem is shown to be NP-complete (CLO7)  What is meant by a reduction in polynomial time? How do we reduce one problem to another one? How do we show a problem to be NP-Complete?
What is meant by a reduction in polynomial time?
How do we reduce one problem to another one?
How do we show a problem to be NP-Complete?

Implement a polynomial-time heuristic algorithm to solve an NP-hard problem (CLO6)  What is meant by a heuristic? What is an approximation ratio? What are some strategies to implement NP-hard problems?
What is meant by a heuristic?
What are some strategies to implement NP-hard problems?
